Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, headset still warm from my last call, when my partner walked in, dropping their bag with a sigh. “Work was a bit much today,” they said, rubbing their temples. I nodded, half-listening, my mind still tangled in the day’s calls. All afternoon, customers had bombarded me with technical questions about our new service—questions my script barely covered. My supervisor expected me to handle every objection smoothly, to never say “I don’t know.” The pressure to sound confident, to keep the call moving, was relentless.

Now, my partner needed me to listen, to offer comfort, to be present. But my thoughts kept drifting back to the calls I’d fumbled, the answers I’d improvised. I wanted to be the supportive spouse they deserved, but my mind was still racing with product specs and rebuttals. I could see the hope in their eyes, waiting for me to ask about their day, to care. At the same time, I felt the weight of my job’s demands pressing in, making it hard to switch gears. I sat there, torn, unsure which role to step into first.
